awd_titl_txt: Rigidity and Buckling of Shells: Toward New Nonlinear Shell Theories
awd_abstract_narration:
The predictions made by classical linear shell theories on the deformation or critical buckling load of thin structures often fail to match the actual performance of such physical structures. Among the several phenomena that may be responsible for this failure is so-called "sensitivity to imperfections," or the highly oscillatory nature of energy minimizers resulting in non-compactness even in very simple geometries like cylinders. The imperfection sensitivity phenomenon poses an ongoing challenge to engineers working with a wide range of thin-shelled structures, from aircraft and automotive components, buildings, poles, and other civil infrastructures, to carbon nanotubes and biopolymer shells. One of the goals of this project is to use the general theory of buckling of thin structures to quantify the imperfection sensitivity phenomenon. Another goal is to solve the longstanding problem of determining the rigidity of a given shell, which is believed to be identified by the principal curvatures of the shell. 

While the problem of determining the rigidity of plates is well understood, determining the rigidity of a given shell has been a longstanding problem in continuum mechanics. Recent results on shells in the linear elasticity setting, with vector fields satisfying Robin boundary conditions on the thin face of the shell, provide evidence that the rigidity of a shell is determined solely by the principal curvatures of the shell's mid-surface. One of the goals of the project is to extend ansatz-free lower bounds to the nonlinear geometric rigidity setting. The strategy is to use existing estimates inducing artificial boundary conditions by test functions as well as a universal Korn interpolation inequality, which reduces the linear geometric rigidity estimate to a Poincar? type estimate. Once this is done, a new hierarchy of shell theories with smaller gaps will naturally follow, which will encompass the existing ones derived by Gamma-convergence. The second part of the project is to further develop the theory of buckling of thin structures. The theory has two ingredients: (i) proving sharp Korn's inequalities, and (ii) proving the existence of bending-free trivial branches. While (i) has been almost entirely done in previous work, (ii) is the goal of the second part of the project. The investigator and collaborators will adopt the approach of quantitative implicit function theorems and quantitative approximation of nonlinear elasticity solutions by the ones in the linear setting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project goal.

This project goal was the study of the Geometric Rigidity, deformation, and buckling of shells and thin structures. While the term "geometric rigidity" is mathematical, it goes well with the physical interpretation of rigidity of a thin structure. If the rigidity of a shell is already determined, the problems of deformation and buckling become much more approachable. Also, there exists a mathematically rigorous mechanism, that allows one to derive shell theories from three-domeinsional nonlinear elasticity using the knowledge on the rigidity of the shell under consideration. All of those problems fall into the scope of the proposed project. 

Outcomes and intelectual merit.

The PI and collaborators have obtained several major results on the proposed project within the award period 07.2018-06.2022. More, precisely seven (7) papers have been written and one (1) is currently in prepartion. The PI has trained graduate student Andre Martins Rodrigues (UCSB) to work on the project. Paper [6] below resulted from this training and collaboration. Graduate student Narek Hovsepyan (Temple University, Rutgers University) has been collaborarting with the PI on the project. Paper [4] resulted from this collaboration. Postdoc Zhirayr Avetisyan (UCSB) was mentored by the PI to work on the project. Paper [4] below resulted from this collaboration. Associate Professor Hayk Mikayelyan (University of Nottingham, Ningbo campus) has been collaborating with the PI, resulting in [7].

[1]. In the paper (sole aothored)  "The asymptotically sharp geometric rigidity interpolation inequality in thin bi-Lipschitz domains" (J. Elasticity, 141, pp. 291-300 (2020)), the PI proves an interpolation analogue of the selebrated Geometric Rigidity Estimate by Friesecke, James, and Mueller, which provides a major progress in the determination of the rigidity of thin domains. This can be regarded as yet another classical result in nonlinear elasticity. 

[2]. In the paper (sole authored) "The sharp L^p Korn interpolation and secon inequalities in thin domains" (SIAM J. Math. Anal., 52(6), 5775-5791, 2020), the PI solves a long standing (a decade old) problem in the theory of linear elasticity, where we calculate the best asymptotic constant in the Korn second inequality for thin domains for Sobolev vector fields under no boundary conditions. Moreover, the PI proves a stronger Korn interpolation inequality for thin domains and Sobolev vector fields with no imposed boundary conditions. This is a major progress in the problem of determination of the linear rigidity of thin domains, and the result can be regarded as a classical elasticity textbook result. 

[3]. The paper (sole authored) "On the geometric rigidity interpolation estimate in thin bi-Lipschitz domains" (C. R. Math. Acad. Sci. Paris, 358 (2020), no. 7, pp. 811-816) is reporting the results in [1] by the prestigeous Paris Academy journal. 

[4]. In the paper (Zh. Avetisyan, D. Harutyunyan, and N. Hovsepyan) "Rigidity of a thin domain depends on the curvature, width, and boundary condition" (Appl. Math. Optim., Vol. 84, pp. 3229-3254 (2021)), provides the geomtric parameters that determine the linear rigidity of a thin domain. 

[5]. In the paper (sole euthored) "A hint on the localiztion of the buckling deformation at vanishing curvature points on thin elliptic shells" (in revision in J. Elasticity, 2022), the PI presents rigorous arguments on why the buckling on thin elliptic shells under dead loding, should localize at the vanishing curvature points.  

[6]. In the paper (D. Harutyunyan and A. M. Rodrigues) "The buckling load of cylindrical shells under axial compression depends on the scoss-section curvature" (in revision in J. Nonlinear Science), the authors provide a link between the buckling load of a cylindrical shell under axial compression and the cross-section curvature. The paper also anwers some long-stansing questions on the so-called sensitivity to imperections in the problem of buckling of shells.

[7]. In the paper (D. Harutyunyan and H. Mikayelyen) "On the fractional Korn inequlity in thin domains" (in revision in Advances in Nonlinear Analysys), the authors prove Korn's first inequality in the fractional setting in bounded smooth domains. 

Broader Impact. 

The PI has created a team of graduate students and a postdoc to woro on the project. This has provided the junior personnel with access to funds and oportunity for training and additional scientiifc educartion. Graduate studet Andre Martins Rodridues (UCDB) has been being traind by the PI to work on the project. Andre has participated in several national conferences to present the obtained results. Graduate student Narek Hovsepyan (Temple University, Rutgers University) has been collaborating with the PI on the project. The PI has invited Narek to UCSB for collaboration, which resulted in one paper. Postdoc Zhirayr Avetisyan has been hired by the PI to collaborate on the project. All the participants have presented the obtained results at various national and internartional conferences and workshops. The PI is a mamber of the "Shell buckling people" platform, where some of the obtained resuts have been posted, which helped a succesfull dissemination. 


Last Modified: 10/28/2022
Modified by: Davit Harutyunyan
